title: BAI-Horse Industry Development: Enhancing the Services of the National Stud Farm Through Research and Development
description:
Horses have been in the Philippines since pre-Hispanic times. Ancestors of the present-day Philippine horse, which were either of Malay and Indian stock, were brought into the country by traders and travelers from Indonesia by way of Sulu or of Chinese bloodlines (Mackie, 1916). These horses were crossed to purebred horses brought in by successive colonizers with the purpose of improving the native breed as they were believed to be small in stature and considered not fit for military use. Horses that were considered “small” were relegated to farm use, for hauling farm produce. Most of these horses were also depended upon as daily conveyance by those who cannot afford to own a horse.

Today, horses still perform a significant role in agriculture and in our daily life. Known for their strength, speed, sure-footedness and intelligence, horses remain as the source of draft power in remote areas. The horse is also popular in equestrian sports such as racing, polo, pleasure-riding and rodeos which generate jobs that stimulate industry and promote tourism. When the need arises, it becomes an alternative source of protein and funds in emergency situations. Several towns still use horses to pull the calesa as an alternative to motorized transport and as a tool to promote tourism. Horse-fighting is also popular in some areas because of cultural practices. The horse is also expected to figure prominently in the promotion of agri-tourism. 

With the important role of horses in Philippine agriculture, it is imperative that support be provided to harness its full potential as work animal, as a potential source of food and livelihood.
This project aims to conserve and improve the Philippine horse as a source draft power, food and livelihood.

title: BFAR - Global Sustainable Supply Chains for Marine Commodities
description:
This project contributes to address key aspects of the market forces that drive overfishing. The project will add to the transformation of the seafood market by mainstreaming sustainability in the value chain of important commodities platforms, and fisheries improvement projects (FIP), developing national capacities, and generating learning to be shared worldwide. The project will allocate GEF resources strategically to 1) engage major seafood buyers in the main world markets (EU, Japan, US) into responsible sourcing, providing tools to prepare and implement sustainable seafood sourcing policies, 2) adapt the concept of green commodities platforms in Costa Rica, Ecuador, Indonesia and Philippines to generate experience that could be used in other countries, 3) support stakeholders of these platforms to develop practical experience with fisheries improvement projects and upgrade existing tools for FIP implementation and monitoring, and 4) upgrade existing information platforms to facilitate access to reliable materials to value chain stakeholders in support of sound decision making, and capturing documenting and disseminating the learnings of the project. The project target fisheries include tuna fisheries in the Pacific Ocean, Mahi-mahi and large pelagic fish in the Eastern Pacific Ocean, Indonesian snapper, Octopus and blue swimming crab fisheries in Philippines.
The project is an inter-regional intervention. Market engagement and knowledge management are global components. The sustainable marine commodities platforms and FIPs will be implemented, using a participatory approach in Costa Rica, Ecuador, Indonesia and Philippines.
updates: This project will start this 2018 and end on 2021.

title: BFAR - Philippine Fisheries and Coastal Resiliency Project
description:
Component 1: Fisheries Coastal Areas Resiliency Planning (FishCARP) -supports spatial planning and developmental policies and guidelines. These may include activities relevant to integrated coastal zone planning focusing on Fisheries Management Areas (FMAs) using Ecosystem Approach to Fisheries Management (EAFM), vulnerable areas of the coast including fishing communities, and nearshore areas using the results of Fisheries Vulnerability/Suitability Assessment Tool (FishVOOL) conducted by NFRDI

Component 2: Fisheries and Coastal-Resilient Resource Management (FishCRRM) - supports management of coastal and marine resources to promote resiliency and sustainable fisheries. Activities under consideration include institutional and procedural strengthening of Marine Protected Areas and coastal habitats; management of fish stocks using modern technologies; development of coastal vegetation, and co-management of municipal waters with coastal communities, law enforcement and certification on fisheries sustainability and traceability

Component 3: Modern and Resilient Fisheries and Aquaculture Enterprises, Infrastructure and Support Facilities - supports modernization of fisheries and aquaculture enterprises throughout the value supply chain including investments on climate-resilient infrastructure, support facilities, system development, credit and insurance access, and logistics. Activities under consideration include development, management and modernization of aquaculture and capture fisheries; adoption of climate-smart production technologies, enhanced entrepreneurial support along with investment in post-harvest facilities, logistics, and improved compliance with manufacturing and food safety and quality standards

Component 4: Project Management and Coordination
The Project Management and Coordination will be set up in the BFAR will be responsible for the everyday activity for this program. It will also coordinate with various implementing agencies and NGOs, and liaise with the funding agency. There will also be an establishment of Project Implementation Units (PIU) at the Regional Fisheries Office that will oversee and be responsible in the field implementation of the activities. As the contribution of the recipient communities and LGUs, FMA Units will be created to coordinate activities with the PMC and the PIU. As a result, the effective and sustainable implementation of the project will be sustained.

title: NDA - Comparative Impact Study of Dairy Farming vs. Pure Crop Farming as Poverty Reduction Strategy
description:
Dairy Farming has always been construed to be a prohibitive and labor-intensive farming activity unlike crop farming.  Government investments have always been hugely spent for rice and high value crops while dairy programs were minimally funded in comparison.  

Statistics show that despite the lack of investments, the growth of the dairy sector has been at an average of 6.3% (2010-2015).  Small hold dairy farmers have considered dairy farming as their livelihood that can provide for their families needs.  The most compelling reason why dairy farmers continue to pursue dairying as a living is profit.

The government, the private sector and future dairy players need to be convinced that dairy farming and all of its related activities are profitable, hence, need investments.  The local dairy industry needs to be promoted as one of the agricultural commodity poverty reduction driver particularly in the rural areas.  Studies shall be documented and backed up by scientific evidence to firm up the cause, hence, this study.

title: NDA - Dairy Goat Farming: A Livelihood Opportunity for Rural Farm families
description:
The proposed program will revolve around a community dairy goat farming concept. In this concept, communities will be identified where dairy goat farms will be established and will function as a goat multiplier farm, dairy production area, and learning site. In this arrangement, farmers will raise the animals given to them by the program in a common area with complete facilities and provision of necessary implements. They will be assisted too in the marketing through the program initiatives.

The implementation of the program will be by module, wherein one beneficiary community will receive one. A module of this program will have the following components: 100 breeder does and 5 breeder bucks; 1 goat house; Developed pasture; Milking and milk processing and storage equipment; Farm implements; Barn and storage; Starting feeds, drugs, and biologics; and Training of recipients.

The beneficiaries shall provide an agricultural land area (minimum of 4 hectares) for the project as a counterpart. The daily operations and accompanying costs of operation will be shouldered by the beneficiaries. The farmer beneficiaries and their families will operate the farm, each owning 10 heads of does. The milk produced will be processed in the farm and will be marketed as a whole. Income will then be divided among the beneficiaries depending on the volume of their production on a day-to-day basis.

In the aspect of marketing, the program had included the milk-feeding strategy to ensure a ready market for the milk produced by the farms. The milk-feeding concept will be an outfit that will buy the milks produced and processed by the modules and bring it for milk-feeding programs for malnourished children in the locality. With this set-up, the program will not only resolve the market obstacle, but will help address malnutrition among children.

This is designed to safeguard the project and the animals from threats like non-compliance of beneficiaries, lack of resources, and poor monitoring and to ensure that the targets are achieved and the recipients will experience the impact of the program in their lives.

It is in this light, that the NDA would like to propose the provision of one (1) agricultural tractor, one (1) forage chopper, one (1) truck, and one (1) warehouse to each of the six (6) Regional Departments of the NDA namely, Northern Luzon, Southern Luzon, Central Visayas, Western Visayas, Northern Mindanao and Southern Mindanao.

The NDA uses this proposed project as the vehicle to support local dairy farmers in their goal of further enhancing dairy farm operations to achieve better milk yield and ensuring the availability of feeds for dairy animals. In addition, the agency seeks to develop more contract growers to serve as feeds source of the local dairy farmers and contract growers for specialized skills in calf rearing and grow-out farming. 

The tractors, trucks, and forage choppers would be provided on hire basis to the local dairy farmers through the NDA Regional Department assisting them. Each department shall be responsible in ensuring the equity in the distribution of assistance to the farmers.

The project will enhance farm operations and increase forage production of local dairy farmers. It also aims to develop more contract growers as feeds source.

title: NDA - Strengthening Capacities of Dairy Farmers & Extension Workers
description:
The National Dairy Authority (NDA) was established in 1995. It is the central policy determining and directing body tasked to ensure the accelerated development of the Philippine dairy industry through policy direction and program coordination and implementation. The main goal of the NDA is to establish a profitable, competitive and sustainable growing dairy industry built on financially viable business performance throughout the value chain, providing good quality of life for farmers and ensuring consumers safe and quality milk and milk products.Majority of the Philippines’s annual dairy requirement is supplied by importers and processors. Local production continues to increase annually but not enough to cover local demand. In 2017 it imported 417,07 million kilograms of milk by 185 importers, processors and traders. In same year local production was only 22,76 million kilograms of milk. Milk is third largest agri-import.Philippines’s dairy sector represents a big potential for an improvement of a quality of life in rural areas. Development of milk production will have positive effects on unemployment rate and socio-economic situation in rural areas.  The NDA is given very limited funds every year to capacitate a total of 2,418 dairy farmers in dairy production and management. The lack of funds contributed to the very limited technical assistance the NDA can provide to these dairy farmers resulting to wrong practices and not enough knowledge to run a dairy enterprise and make it profitable.

The NDA is focused on improvement of situation. In 2017, the NDA and Czech Republic’s Development Assistance (program Aid for Trade of the Ministry of Industry and Trade of the Czech Republic) have started a new project focused on situation of dairy sector in Philippines - “Assistance in analyzing and improving value chains in the dairy industry in Philippines”. In scope of the project, Czech dairy experts have visited Philippines’s farms. They have identified three main issues that are complicating development of dairy industry in Philippines:
insufficient capacities of extension workers
- insufficient capacities of dairy farmers 
- insufficient promotion of local (Philippines’s) production and consumption

The proposed project is consistent with and directly supports the NDA Charter Statement and Strategy Map (Annex A) of improving the stakeholders’ welfare, ensuring the enforcement of dairy quality standards from production to post-harvest, advocate for the patronage of local milk and milk products and enhancing the competency of NDA manpower and farmer-clients.
Finally, the proposed project will help realize the Philippine Agriculture’s goals of expanding opportunities for those engaged in agriculture production and increasing access of small and subsistence farmers to economic opportunities as stipulated in Chapter 8 of the Philippine Development Plan (PDP) 2017-2022.

title: PCC - National Dairy Herd Improvement Program (NDHIP) and Enterprise Build Up
description:
The Dairy Herd Improvement Program (DHIP) is sometimes referred to as DHI, DHIA, or DHIR specifically for large animals. This valuable tool helps evaluate the progress of the herd’s milk production while addressing the improvement of the different production management system including breeding, health and nutrition. Through the DHIP, the breeding program of the carabaos at the local level will have a clear direction and its progress is measured over time to ensure that the animals are improving in terms of breeding performance. The DHIP is fairly inexpensive, useful and exciting activity that only requires constant monitoring and evaluation including documentation of activities.

In addition, the dairy herd improvement (DHI) system has a played a critical role in the advancement of the dairy industry.  Even today, it remains an important link in the industry. However, dairy industry changes, such as animal number decreases and shifts, dairy management advances, and on-farm economics, pose significant challenges to DHI. The nature of the dairy market, changing technology, and competitive pressures indicate the need for strategic planning and implementation among DHI participants, players and stakeholders.

The project is expected to benefit some 150,000 dairy farmers and 190 organized groups.
updates: The project has been presented to the DA-wide Clearinghouse Committee. The proposal is currently being revised for resubmission to DA Clearinghouse, and subsequent endorsement to NEDA. Since the project will be funded by ODA-Grant, it is possible that the project will commence by 2020.

title: PhilFIDA - Abaca Tuxy Buying Special Project (ATBSP)
description:
The Abaca Tuxy Buying Special Project (ATBSP) is the new approach to be implemented by the Philippine Fiber Industry Development Authority (PhilFIDA) in the production of excellent abaca fiber. This scheme will ensure the survival of abaca which is indigenous to the Philippines. Using a corporative approach, the project aims to organize and empower most of the abaca farmers nationwide as a cooperative, produce their own abaca fibers as a group which will redound to better competitive price, quality and quantity and sell their harvest directly to Grading and Baling Establishments (GBEs) and local processors. A group of abaca farmers with contiguous abaca farms for at least one hectare per farmer shall be formed into a cooperative with at least 100 active farmer-members and should be accredited with the Department of Agriculture (DA).  This project also aims to reduce the activity being done by the farmers to increase their productivity. The traditional way of abaca fiber extraction/harvesting by the abaca farmers has twelve (12) stages.  The project intends to lessen it to only six (6) steps --Topping, Tumbling, Tuxying, Tuxy Bundling, Tuxy Transporting/Hauling and Tuxy Trading /Selling --  thereby removing and easing the burden of the abaca farmers of the other six (6) activities and just let them continue producing all the abaca tuxies they want for the day before selling it to their cooperative that same day. This will surely increase abaca fiber production.

The project has an estimated budgetary requirement of about P20 million to cover the warehouse, stripping, drying and office buildings, equipment and facilities, hauling truck and motorcycles and seed capital for the initial operation. Feasibility study and logical framework was conducted and formulated thus, ready for takeoff once budget is available.

ATBSP is aligned to the newly approved Abaca Industry Roadmap of PhilFIDA. It is expected to meet the demand for the high-quality abaca fibers and uplift the status of life of abaca farmers most specially the indigenous people in rural areas.
updates: with completed project proposal, feasibility study and detailed engineering design
expected_outputs: The project aims to increase income of abaca farmers who are members of an abaca farmer cooperative under the Abaca Tuxy Buying Special Project by at least 100%.

title: PhilFIDA - Cotton Development Project
description:
The demand for tropical fibers in the production of locally-made fabrics for use in government offices and functions per R.A. 9242, s. 2004, and the need to supply the requirement for raw materials of local weavers and knitters make the support to the Philippine fiber industry imperative.    

Cotton, as a primary component of home-made fabrics, having been grown for long in the country as an industry, is among the major fibers that need to be revitalized and sustained. The Philippines used to produce cotton supplying a portion of the need of the textile mills in the country. Highest production was attained in 1992 when area planted to cotton reached 35,000 hectares and produced 14,400 MT raw cotton fiber (cotton lint). However, due to serious economic and technical considerations on cotton growing in recent years, there had been a substantial decline in hectarage and participation in the industry, with areas just primarily confined in research stations to date. 

 In as much as a home-grown cotton production technology had been developed, along with the availability of physical resources that convert cotton harvests into raw fiber, waiting to be refurbished for immediate use, cotton cultivation and processing can be sustained with proper support from the government. 

To revitalize the cotton industry in order to sustain the production of cotton fibers for small-scale cotton users, such as local loom-weavers and knitters, and eventually for commercial-size cotton production and utilization.

title: PhilFIDA - PhilFIDA ICT Project
description:
Technical assistance and advisory services, information, education and communication support services for farmers’ groups and agricultural technicians of the Local Government Units (LGUs) and training services are among those banner programs of PhilFIDA. Information needed in the implementation of these programs is dispersed to all provincial and regional offices. Obtaining such information from one office to another may cause some difficulty and a possible duplication of efforts in maintaining similar systems and/or databases across different field offices occurs due to the geographical concerns. Obviously, there is a need to integrate information sources and build-up an agency-wide knowledge databank and up-to-date web portal to ensure easy access to updated, relevant and timely information. Improvement of electronic links within the organization as well as with the other external entities is also necessary. 

Data and information systems on the geographical location of programs and projects of the agency presented in electronic maps are also needed to be developed for effective monitoring and to reduce the need for clients to physically go to PhilFIDA offices to avail of services or obtain the information they need. An improved internal system can be better delivered through the use of latest technologies on intranet and extranet solutions, particularly through web-enabled applications.

Voice and data communication technologies can manage coordinative works between central office and different provincial and regional offices. Centralized system within the agency will further enhance productivity through web-enabled applications.

The ISSP aims to guide PhilFIDA in the implementation of its ICT initiatives and projects to enhance its performance and achieve its goals. This also includes the proposed ICT organizational structure to cope with changing requirements and fast-paced technology.

This ISSP covers the Central Office, Laboratories, Experimental Stations and all Regional and Provincial Offices of PhilFIDA.

description:

Identification of new uses for natural fibers to promote their utilization development and identification of new uses for natural fibers to promote their utilization in line with environment  conciousness for green economy and utilization of renewable resources; 1.3  Raw material manipulation of fibers to create a variety of different effects using fibers, fabrics and other materials for the different fiber properties 1.4 Disseminate developed  technologies as technology source for community -based livelihood project in coordination with ESETS. title: Philippine Rural Development Project
description:
PRDP is a six-year national government platform for a modern and climate-smart agriculture to be pursued through partnerships with local government units and agri-fishery stakeholders. It will take-off from the gains and lessons of various DA programs such as project tracking by geo-tagging and building capacity of LGUs and farming and fishing communities to manage and sustain agri-fishery support infrastructure and services, among others.
The Project will operationalize the national and regional Agriculture and Fishery Modernization Plans (AFMPs) through integration of plans at the provincial level. Also, the Project will be guided by the vulnerability and suitability assessment framework, which was initially used for the Central Philippines Rural Development Project (CPRDP) preparation. Also, it will develop value chain roadmaps that will serve as an input in the selection and prioritization of investments in the target areas.

The Project is aligned with the goals and priorities of the Philippine Development Plans (2011-2016) for a competitive and sustainable agriculture and fisheries sectors, will provide program-level support for the Agriculture and Fisheries Modernization Act of 1997 (RA 8435) and advances the principles of Agrikulturang Pinoy (AgriPinoy) of sustainable resource management, local development and full service delivery from farm to table.

Local Planning: this component aims to enhance the Agricultural and Fisheries Modernization Plan through science-based tools and to harmonize regional and provincial Agriculture and Fisheries Modernization Plan through the formulation of the Provincial Commodity Investment Plan using value chain approach.

Infrastructure Development: this component aims to improve the links from production areas to markets to enhance the efficiency of transporting agricultural products. It also aims for higher productivity as a result of increased cropping intensity and yields, food security and improved health from readily available potable water and lower post harvest losses resulting in higher volume of outputs and more efficient support facilities.

Enterprise Development: this component aims to engage broad sections of the sector in the production of marketable surplus through investments in strategic segments of priority commodity value chains and strengthening collaboration between DA and the Local Government Units. It shall strengthen and develop viable agri-fishery based enterprises through efficient value chain of key regional agri-fishery product.

Project Support: this component aims to provide efficient and effective project management and implementation, establish a standard on services and technical assistance and effective mode of engagement with LGUs.
implementation_risk: (1) Project Stakeholders: The risks associated with resistance and/or slow uptake of the institutional reforms in the DA on which PRDP is built on appears to be diminishing as project implementation proceeds. The Project through the Local and National Level Planning Component will release a Harmonized Planning and Budgeting Manual. that will encompass planning & Budgeting, investment planning and monitoring and evaluation manuals. This will be distributed to all DA offices, agencies, bureau, corporation. others. (2) Governance of the Implementing Agency: The risk of governance issues within the DA and as they relate to LGUs in implementing the PRDP are increasingly diminishing as implementation of the Project gathers momentum. A high degree of staff, unit/bureau and attached agency support has been developed through active program of institutional and stakeholder assessments, workshop and briefings. (3) Social and Environmental: The MRDP 2 Environmental and Management Framework and Guidelines (EMFG) have been updated to ensure that PRDP  subprojects meet the requirements/compliance on Social and Environmental aspects.

title: PRRI - Decision Support System for Rubber Production Using Geographical Information System (GIS) and Remote Sensing Technology
description:
The development of sustainable and improved production of rubber industry is anchored on proper and well-developed decision making, enhanced productivity to adopt new technology and innovation. An inclusive and globally competitive rubber industry providing sustainable benefits to all stakeholders is envisioned for the Philippine rubber industry, with the goal of increasing the benefits of all the stakeholders, thereby spreading the gains down to the smallholders in the remote barangays in all rubber producing provinces in the regions. For the past year, low production of rubber yield emerges as a major constraint in the rubber industry which is mainly attributed in low pricing, in addition the improper fertilization management/nutrient management, emergence of pests and diseases, uses of unsuited rubber clones for plantation, lack of information on rubber clone agronomic characteristics and natural calamities. The development of technologies to support decision-making in production, pricing, good agricultural practices, market, pest and diseases management. The derived information will be useful for the farmers, planners, and researchers. Philippines Rubber Research Institute (PRRI) needs timely accurate statistics on natural rubber regularly to monitor and to take suitable measures in the interest of the Philippines rubber sector.	

Generally, this study will enable the Philippine Rubber Research Institute (PRRI) to map the areas vulnerable to soil erosion, estimating the area for further cultivation, and clone suitability map through GIS and Remote Sensing technologies. Furthermore this study will assess the spatial distribution of rubber area over different classes of elevation and slope and the traditional rubber clone’s farmer’s preference, it will help to fully understand the dynamics of rubber plantation activity in the rubber traditional regions of the Philippines and understanding the variation in the productivity of rubber ecosystem in the Philippines.

Present technologies may not be suitable for the next/coming years. Slow internet connection may affect the activities in the field. Needs timely accurate data and accuracy of geographical information may affect the project implementation. Logistics, safety and health concern on the project proponents (socio - political concern (e.g. environment, crime, service may not equitable to the society involved, social attitude towards modernization) , infectious diseases (e.g. malaria, dengue).

Mitigation Strategies: Close coordination to the concern agencies to lay down different responsibilities. Establishing contact/networking with the rubber farmer cooperators for their availability, transportation and mobility and other administrative matters/issues to and determination of the desired approach to improve the program. Upgrading and updating the systems to follow the trend of the changing technology.
updates: Crafting of proposal methodologies. This program was presented during the collegial review for possible correction and recommendation for the enhancement of the program. Furthermore, approval of the approving bodies is the next steps which will be done before the end of the year.

 2. Generate data on the location of rubber.
 3. Create suitable measures in the interest of Rubber sector.
 4. Expansion of production and improvement of plantation/farm productivity by adopting recommended technology and good agricultural practices.

Hence, this program aims to address this seemingly insurable crisis in the Philippine rubber economy.  Republic Act 10089 states, "undertake training and capacity-building programs for rubber producers, processors and cooperatives in order to increase production of quality rubber and raises level of income especially of poor smallholders." Given this function, PRRI shall conduct trainings/seminars/workshops to essentially capacitate the rubber smallholders, specifically the rubber farmers so that they will be alleviated from their former state of only earning meager income. Training to be conducted will enhance the knowledge and skills of rubber farmers in rubber plantation, and nursery and bud wood garden establishment and management, harvesting and post-harvesting of rubber to increase the productivity and improve the quality of rubber thus increase the income of rubber farmers.

title: PRRI - Leaf Morpho-anatomy and Molecuclar Characterization Of Seven Recommended and 2000 series Hevea brasiliensis in the Philippines
description:
Seven recommended clones  (USM1, RRIM 600, PB 260, PB 330, PB 217, PB 235, PB 311) and 200 series rubber clones that are utilized for large scale planting possess unique characteristics which are adaptable in different agro-climatic conditions in diverse locations. However, some of the commercial rubber nurseries which are not accredited supply rubber seedlings that are not yet identified. This is due to the multiple combinations of different clones without proper recording such as lay-outing and tagging. Unidentified rubber clones gives a detrimental effect in clonal purity and in result, hampers the overall productivity of rubber.

This project aims to characterize the seven recommended and 200 series clones in the Philippines through morphological, anatomical, and molecular methods for proper clone identification of distributed rubber budded seedlings.

title: PRRI - Mapping Incidence and Distribution of Major Pests and  Diseases of Rubber in the Zamboanga Peninsula
description:
The rubber tree is subject to a plethora of economically important pathological problems, mainly of fungal origin, the Basidiomycetes. Pests and diseases of rubber could prevent and reduce the full yield potential in the rubber industry. 

Limited information can be found regarding the distribution of termite pest and fungal diseases of rubber in the Philippines. Knowledge on the spatial distribution of these diseases in and among rubber plantations and on consequences related to disease infection or disorder and eventual latex yield loss is important to consider in formulating effective integrated disease management strategies. This is also critical in sustaining the rubber industry especially in rehabilitating senile rubber plantations as planting materials can be severely infected to fungal diseases present in the field or from the neighboring rubber plantations. GIS maps are one of the tools in forecasting disease outbreaks and estimating damage and consequently in designing cost-effective and location-specific pest and disease management strategies appropriate for different cropping systems in the Zamboanga Peninsula. Thus, this study will potentially support the lack of technical knowledge of rubber farmers on rubber production and management especially on the control of pests and diseases in the region.
expected_outputs: One (1) production-related research and development activity conducted

title: PRRI - Nursery Selection and Seedling Evaluation Trial of Promising Ortet Clone Potential for Hevea Breeding in Zamboanga Sibugay
description:
Havea brasiliensis is a perennial out-breeder with a long lifespan which makes crop improvement laborious and time consuming. Breeding cycle in rubber extends to 20-30 years between pollination and yield assessment distributed over three selection stages. This justifies standardization of early selection methods to optimize and shorten the cycle as much as possible and one component of early selection is identification of traits at young age that have correlated response with yield at maturity and the other is combined management of different selection stages to improve the accuracy of estimation of genetic value.

This aims to determine the growth and yield performance of the ortet seedlings and discuss the observations on juvenile screening in Hevea breeding.

title: PRRI - Production Performance of Matured Rubber Trees Applied with Low Tapping Frequency at Varrying Levels of Latex Stimulants
description:
The cultivation of rubber trees (Hevea brasiliensis) in the Philippines is predominantly played by small rubber farmers holding only three hectares or less. With the unstable current market price of natural rubber latex, most tappers seek other income generating activity to augment the families’ basic needs that solely depend on rubber latex production. Thus, the rubber industry is facing a scarcity of skilled tapper laborers. Tapping is the most costly activity in natural rubber production and the shortage of tappers is a serious problem in rubber plantations in the country. Low Frequency Tapping (LFT) systems are considered to be a solution to these issues by reducing the number of tappers required while increasing tappers' income.

Therefore, the need to improve the productivity and competitiveness of rubber cultivation is compulsory such as reduction of tapping labor and applying low tapping frequencies that may lessen the operational cost and can increase the marginal profit of rubber farmers. This activity will be compensated by the increase of hormonal stimulation by providing latex stimulant. With this tapping orientation, the profit of rubber tappers may increase since they will not solely depend on rubber tapping as their source of income.

title: PRRI - Screening of Introduced Hevea brasiliensis Clones and Hevea camargoana Species for Susceptibility and Resistance Under Corynespora Leaf Fall Disease Induced Condition
description:
Corynespora Leaf Fall Disease (CLFD) caused by a fungal pathogen Corynespora cassiicola is one of the major diseases which poses serious threat to natural rubber production in rubber growing countries of South and South East Asia (Edathil et.al. 2000).This disease is regularly causing more damage in any plant growth stages (i.e. nursery, immature and mature trees). Occurrence of this disease causes repeated post wintering defoliation that adversely affect the tree, resulting in reduced production and yield loss can be of more than 45 per cent. 

In order to keep the sustainability of quality rubber production, there is a need to have an efficient disease management strategy in modern rubber growing. Despite the economic effect of CLF disease-causing pathogen on commercially grown rubber in the Philippines, screening for susceptibility among clones as a method to improve the management of this disease have not been examined. Thus, this study aims to identify and evaluate potential susceptible and resistant clones and specie to Corynespora Leaf Fall disease from introduced Hevea clones and specie by inducing CLFD-pathogen to the leaves of seedlings of different rubber clones in nursery to determine whether clonal variation could be used to better manage the disease problem.

title: PRRI - Utilization of Activated Carbon from Agricultural Waste Products for Natural Rubber Wastewater Treatment in Zamboanga Peninsula
description:
Rubber industry is an economically important industry in Western Mindanao, Philippines. The significant plantations in the Philippines are located in Zamboanga Peninsula. On the other hand, wastewater treatment is becoming more critical because of the diminishing water resources, increasing cost of wastewater disposal, and firmer regulations in connection to the contaminant levels in waste streams. 

Adsorption technique is an efficient process for the treatment of wastewater from various industrial plants. But this technique highly relies on the used adsorbent. The low-cost adsorbent should be easily available, abundant in nature, or a waste product from industrial and agricultural sectors. Agricultural products such as carabao manure, coconut shell, rice hull and saw dust due to its chemical composition such as holocellulose, lignin, and ash. Precursor materials can be activated using chemical agents (oxidizing agents) that will be utilized in wastewater treatment of natural rubber processing plants. 

This project aims to produce and utilize activated carbon from carabao manure for the treatment of water effluent from natural rubber processing plant	.
updates: The project was approved during PRRI Collegial review last August 23, 2019. It is still on its preparation stage where research proposal is under revision as per instruction of the panel of evaluators. Research proposal will be packaged and signed before the end of the year.
expected_outputs: One (1) research project conducted on the usage of activated carbon from agricultural waste products that can be used in wastewater treatment of rubber processing plants

title: Special Area for Agricultural Development (SAAD) Program
description:
In support to the thrust of President Duterte to increase food production and reduce poverty, the DA’s SAAD was conceptualized. It intends to contribute in alleviating poverty through increased food production and establishment of community enterprises in the target areas by providing the appropriate technology, marketing, and other support services in order to make the farmers and fisherfolk productive and profitable.

Generally, the Program hopes to help alleviate poverty in the areas where it operates through the provision of agricultural and related interventions to the farming and fisheries sector. Specifically, it aims to:

1. Complement the DA regular programs in terms of beneficiaries and interventions;
2. Improve food production for household consumption and commercial purpose in areas of operation; and
3. Assist beneficiaries establish communal agricultural enterprises

expected_outputs: The Program wants to have significant impact by trying to contribute to poverty reduction in its areas of operation by increasing income, improving economic status, and improving the household food consumption of its partner beneficiaries.
